An Introduction to the Bootstrap
A reference work on the bootstrap method, clear and comprehensive (the first author devised the method
Brigitte Escofier and Jerome Pages: Analyses Factorielles Simples et Multiples, Dunod
A very comprehensive book, helpful for the reader who wishes to be able to read a factor analysis
Slinker: Primer of Applied Regression and Analysis of Variance
A very full description of linear regression and analysis of variance, with an introduction to the Cox semi-parametric survival models
Multivariate Data Analysis

container-title: with SAS and SPSS syntax, and an interpretation of the outputs. It also covers data cleaning and missing values
title: A real doorstop of a book (more than 900 pages), but full of excellent and accessible practical information, without too many equations. It provides examples of each type of analysis (factor analysis, canonical analysis, MANOVA, multiple regression, discriminant analysis, conjoint analysis, structural equations, etc
Information Generation: How Data Rule Our World
An excellent survey of statistics and its place in the modern world, written in a clear and attractive style by a leading expert, of interest to statisticians and others
Hand: Statistics: A Very Short Introduction
A very useful introduction to statistics, detailed and concise, covering the basics of the subject, from data collection to modelling and computing, via probability theory and inference
Hosmer and Stanley Lemeshow: Applied Logistic Regression

A well-known work on logistic regression, with numerous examples from the field of biostatistics. Starting from a basic knowledge of the linear model, this book provides a remarkably clear explanation of the principles and applications of logistic regression
Statistique Exploratoire Multidimensionnelle: Visualisations et Inferences en Fouille de Donnees, Dunod

One of the best titles on ‘French-style’ data analysis (factor analysis), also covering developments in clustering, discriminant analysis, log-linear models, decision trees, neural networks, validation methods, etc
Multivariate Analysis
This book is less recent and does not cover subjects such as the bootstrap, but it is still a standard work on multivariate analysis, noted for its clear and elegant presentation of the subject
Nelder: Generalized Linear Models
Data Mining Techniques: for Marketing, Sales, and Customer Relationship Management

A readable book on data mining, more useful for its examples than its technical content (it does not cover factor analysis, discriminant analysis, logistic regression, or their more recent developments
Mastering Data Mining: The Art and Science of Customer Relationship Management
The second book on data mining by the same authors, with 20 case studies
Olshen, and C.J

container-title: Principles and Theory for Data Mining and Machine Learning
title: A basic work on decision trees, written by the inventors of CART
A recent reference work on data mining, methods of selecting variables, clustering, regression, ensemble methods, etc., with numerous examples for which the R code is provided
Pattern Classification, Wiley-Interscience

A new edition of the classic from 1973, also very well illustrated, accompanied by exercises, covering numerous techniques ranging from neural networks to Markov models, taking in mixture models for clustering, with interesting sections on the bias–variance dilemma, overfitting and ensemble methods
Applied Data Mining: for Business and Industry

note: Hand, Heikki Mannila, and Padhraic Smyth: Principles of Data Mining, MIT Press, 2001.
title: This book is aimed at a broad spectrum of readers interested in data mining, applied statistics, databases and econometrics, providing a simple description of data mining in the 150-page introductory section. The second part presents seven case studies, each ten pages long, in the following fields: web mining, market basket analysis, credit risk, lifetime value, etc. The question of software is considered and some of the case studies use R
There is a version with a CD-ROM of SAS code included
Ripley: Pattern Recognition and Neural Networks
A very good review of the state of the art and the theoretical bases of neural networks
Vapnik: The Nature of Statistical Learning Theory

A ‘historic’ survey of statistical learning theory by one of its main proponents, with a concise description of his contribution, and an introduction to support vector machines (and to support vector regression in the
Vapnik: Statistical Learning Theory

A much longer and more demanding work than the previous one, dealing with the theoretical bases of the concepts of learning, VC dimension and structural risk minimization, and detailing the theory and practice of support vector machines
Data Mining Solutions: Methods and Tools for Solving Real-World Problems
A useful reference work, especially for those interested in visual methods
Witten and Eibe Frank: Data Mining: Practical Machine Learning Tools and Techniques
Much appreciated for its clarity and simplicity as well as its practical aspects
The Top Ten Algorithms in Data Mining
Text mining Ludovic Lebart and Andre
Exploring textual data, Kluwer, Dordrecht. An enthralling classic account
Mylene Bazsalicza and Patrick Na€ım: Data mining pour le Web
A book with a strongly educational approach, which starts by discussing the basics of the Internet and data mining and goes on to describe the statistical processing of web data
Mining the Web
The latest title from the well-known consultants of
SAS for Dummies
A basic reference
SAS Version 9.2: Introduction au decisionnel: methode et maıtrise du langage
